comments:
HCMG 215 provides an overview of the management, economic and policy issues facing the pharmaceutical, biotechnology, and medical device industries. The course has a global perspective but with emphasis on the U.S. as the largest and most profitable market. Critical issues examined include: R&D intensive cost structure and rapid technological change; biotechnology and genomics startups and alliances with the pharmaceutical industry; a complex global marketplace in which prices are regulated in most countries and customers include governments and insurers, as well as physicians, pharmacists and consumers now reachable through DTC; intense and evolving M&A; government regulation of every business function: R&D, pricing, manufacturing, and promotion; and global products and multinational firms. Industry and Wharton experts from various disciplines will come in to address these issues.

Students commented that they learned a great deal in this class. They also thought the information was “exceptionally well presented.”

Students praised Professor Danzon for her vast knowledge of the industry and for being a leader in her field. Many thought she was the best professor they had encountered at Penn and referred to her as a “gem.” The guest speakers were universally well-liked and appreciated for their perspective being close to the industry.

While students enjoyed the course, some commented that there was too much required reading. A few students wished there had been a more visible connection linking the information between lectures, but were overall very interested in what was presented to them.
